title: Data advocacy
body:
Open and shared data can be valuable resources for any business. Whether to develop a clearer picture of operations, reduce inefficiency in supply chains or increase reach, a growing number of organisations now benefit from publishing and using both open and shared data.

But to share or open data might require a change in the culture of an organisation. Most businesses are configured to protect their data resources, even where benefits of greater sharing outweigh costs. The key to overcoming this resistance is clear, effective communication of the benefits that open and shared data can bring.

This module will prepare you to deliver a tailored pitch for open data that highlights value and addresses risks.

In this module we’ll explore the following:
  • What elements make up the perfect pitch for open data
  • How to tailor your pitch to specific audiences
  • Where to find relevant case studies
  • How to deliver a pitch for open data

title: The five components of the perfect open data pitch
displayTitle: The five components of the perfect open data pitch
body:
Creating an effective pitch for open data requires five elements. These elements are common to most 'elevator pitches' and combine to create a clear, compelling case for action. The pitch should be delivered in 90 seconds or less.

The five components of the perfect pitch are:
  • What it is – a plain definition of the concept
  • What is does – a tailored description of the benefit
  • Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  • Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  • What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

Below we explore each of these elements in greater detail.

title: What is data?
body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

title: What makes data open?
body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

The value of open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.

title: What open data does
body: Open data can bring different benefits, depending on its use. Many advocates of open data use generic arguments when discussing its advantages, but a strong pitch for open data needs to be closely tailored to the priorities and concerns of its audience. In most cases, this can be determined from their professional context. Below we examine six common roles of decision makers, coupled with the most relevant benefits of open data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: Leadership and strategy
_items.body:
Most organisations already have or are exploring the need for a data strategy. When speaking with those in strategic or leadership roles, strengthening their data strategy is a key concern.

Open data supports the wider data strategy of an organisation by enriching proprietary data at no cost and adding new options to the data-sharing capabilities of the business.

_items.title: Operations
_items.body:
For those in operations roles, efficiency is a priority. Data plays a role in resource-saving by enabling a faster exchange of information. Open data can enable efficiency in orders of far greater magnitude.

The ability to access and share data across multiple platforms and between numerous organisations eradicates the time and cost normally associated with acquiring valuable datasets, one by one.

_items.title: Finance or ventures
_items.body:
Those working in finance or ventures will want to know that the investment they put into open data will bring about value for the organisation. When speaking to those in a ventures capacity, the high growth potential of open data services, and initial value they will create, support a strong case for open data. Open data can produce viable equity ventures and business lines with businesses like Climate Corp, DataMarket and others have been acquired wholly by larger organisations.

Open data has already created attractive target entities for acquisition and can contribute to the creation of viable independent business units.

_items.title: Communications
_items.body:
For those in communications roles, data can seem irrelevant to their work. The key message that resonates with communications professionals is that opening data maximises opportunities for media exposure in support of promoting organisational priorities, and complements existing media channels.

Opening data has a proven track record in helping to secure positive media coverage. The rise of data journalism has created a need for alternative channels that traditional releases and media alerts cannot reach. Open data also increases perceived neutrality and trust among the public that resulting articles are not ‘spun’.

_items.title: CSR or foundations
_items.body:
Those who work in CSR or foundations have the greatest natural inclination towards open data. Along with the transparency aspect, this audience responds well to the way in which open data helps to found and strengthen new partnerships.

Exchanging open data with other organisations supports collaboration within existing networks and creates an open platform for innovation and shared learning. By engaging with open data, you can increase your long-term profits and shareholder trust.

_items.title: Product or marketing
_items.body:
Those in product or marketing roles will respond best to the potential of open data to enhance relationships with customers. More consumers are coming to expect a custom experience, which can be satisfied through greater provision of open data to complement the product function.

Open data has already enabled startups like CityMapper and OpenCorporates to thrive, shifting the expectations of consumers in their respective markets for not only the product but for the underlying data. Also, as an established businesses, Spotify uses open data service MusicBrainz to enhance the listening experience for its users and develop a competitive edge.

_items.title: Comms and transparency
_items.body:
As a large organisation, agricultural product company Syngenta are reaching new markets and demystifying their work by publishing openly available datasets.

In the public sector, analysis of openly available Canada Revenue Agency data identified $3.2bn in charitable tax violations. In one case, only $1 out of every $100 went to its stated cause of helping the homeless.

As an open data startup, OpenCorporates provides 100m company records in over 100 jurisdictions, which enables the study of beneficial ownership and control.

_items.title: Generating income
_items.body:
Another large organisation, Arup, incubates open data startups for new revenue sources and lower operations costs for services, and to collaboratively gain commercial insight into multiple data releases.

The Climate Corporation was bought by Monsanto for $930m in 2013 for their use of farm data, which has revolutionised the agricultural industry.

In startups, Transport API have an annual turnover of £300k, generated by cleaning up UK transport data for other businesses.

_items.title: Efficiency savings
_items.body:
Thomson Reuters is another large organisation, who has applied open data so that their existing products can be linked together for a better sales channel, which has lowered ownership costs.

In the public sector, the Government of South Australia saves $3.2m annually on Freedom of Information requests through proactively releasing data.

Startup Prescribing Analytics – a joint venture between NHS doctors and technologists – used open data to identify a £200m annual saving for the NHS if they were to switch to own-brand statins and utilise more efficient delivery routes.

_items.title: Improving services
_items.body:
Another large organisation, Transport for London, released their travel data and enabled developers to provide consumer-friendly services, providing customers with an estimated £58 million per year in saved time.

In the public sector, the government of Catalunya achieved savings of €2.6m per year in reduced staff costs from cross-department access to map data.

Startup CityMapper joined up available transport data to improve the ways in which citizens could travel. Three years after its inception, CityMapper has received $10m in funding and has expanded to cover 29 cities.

_items.title: CSR and social impact
_items.body:
In the large organisation category, the Environment Agency used open data to create community-built flood models that could save 20% on design and delivery costs of providing mandatory flood information to the public.

In the public sector, in response to the Christchurch earthquake in 2011, city officials and volunteers created a crowdsourced emergency information web app that saved NZ$4m in reconstruction costs within the first year of rebuilding.

Startup OpenSensors deployed air quality and noise sensors around Heathrow, which they released as open data, exposing the fact that emissions were double the reported figure and altering the direction of parliamentary debate on the subject.

title: Why open data is best
body: Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Unlike resources generally used in a traditional business, which belong only to the business and can be protected, open data can be used by others at the same time. To understand how businesses that use open data operate, we need to consider the value proposition of open data to a business.
instruction: Click below to explore tools that unlock data that is on the Web

_items.alt: What is a value proposition of open data?
_items.title: What is a value proposition of open data?
_items.body: A 'value proposition' is a credible justification for why your customers will interact with your business in the ways that you expect. At the core of a value proposition is the problem you solve for your customers. By identifying a problem your customers have and creating a solution to that problem, you give them justification to interact with your business.

_items.title: Why are value propositions important?
_items.body: The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business does not have justification to operate. The value proposition is also the logic upon which the rest of the business is based. If, for example, a business solves a problem for its customers and helps them to save money or time, there is a reason to charge for this service. If, however, the solution that a business offers is not one that customers value in monetary terms, the business may need to seek alternative sources of revenue. Understanding their value proposition allows a business to anchor decisions in how customers will interact.

_items.title: The value proposition of open
_items.body: Businesses embracing an open approach – whether in open source software or open data – need to consider the value proposition of the open resources that they consume. This consideration is important when developing a value proposition, because using someone else's data or software in your business can affect the problem you solve.

_items.alt: Creating a value proposition for an open data business
_items.title: Creating a value proposition for an open data business
_items.body: Creating the value proposition for an open data business is different from a traditional business. Where a closed business solves a problem with a solution that the customer cannot get anywhere else, an open business uses solutions that are already available in some form elsewhere. This means that the value proposition for an open business is usually based on being more convenient or cost-effective than the alternatives. Writing a strong value proposition for an open data business means explaining what problem you solve for a customer and why using your solution is better than going directly to the data themselves.

title: What next?
body:
Once you have made the key points in your pitch for open data, it is vital that you create the conditions for action. Listeners want to be able to take action in response to a pitch. Your task is to create an action that allows them to immediately say yes (or no), without needing to go away to consider it.

Creating an action that someone can decide on at the time means that you are not asking for too much. If the person would need to consult others or consider further, the action is too big. The ideal is an action that is small, clear, and moves the agenda forward.

Good actions include: getting a date in the diary for a follow-up meeting with more people; a commitment to read and respond to a case study relevant to their interests; or them sending a feasibility assessment of using your solution.

Keep the timeframe and impact clear. Finally, only ask for budget or time that is reasonable, given the level of expected return.

title: Are you ready for open data advocacy?
displayTitle: Are you ready for open data advocacy?
body: There are four helpful things to remember when advocating for open data. Can you remember them?

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses
data that anyone can access, use and share
data that is visible on the Web

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.
Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.
Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and must also be available for commercial use
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.
Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and must also be available for commercial use

title: Benefits of open data
body: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of open data?

_items.text: Open data produces viable equity ventures and business lines
Open data helps improve media coverage and increase reach
Open data improves personal features and smoothes personality flaws
Open data improves outreach and forges social partnerships

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Among other benefits, open data can create viable ventures, increase media reach and forge new partnerships

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Among other benefits, open data can create viable ventures, increase media reach and forge new partnerships

title: Proof points
body: Which of the following is NOT a genuine proof point for the benefits of open data?

_items.text: The National Weather Service was bought by Monsanto in 2013 for their use of rain data, which has revolutionised the agricultural industry
The government of Catalunya achieved savings of €2.6m per year in reduced staff costs from cross-department access to map data
Prescribing Analytics identified a £200m annual saving in NHS by switching to own-brand statins and more efficient delivery routes

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

This never happened. Refer back to 'Where Open Data Has Helped' to read back on genuine proof points.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?
This never happened. Refer back to 'Where Open Data Has Helped' to read back on genuine proof points.

_graphic.alt: Why do we need open data?

title: Next steps
body: Which of these next steps would be a good end to an open data pitch?

_items.text: Get a date in the diary with relevant stakeholders to discuss how to take it forward
Send all the datasets that could be opened to stakeholders for immediate sign off
Send a 2000-2500 word proposal to stakeholders to convince them to start utilising or publishing data
Do nothing – the data will open itself

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Getting a date in the diary to continue the discussion with the right people is a good way to move things forward

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Getting a date in the diary to continue the discussion with the right people is a good way to move things forward
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Getting a date in the diary to continue the discussion with the right people is a good way to move things forward

title: Open data - veni, vidi, vici
body: Open data can be a confusing concept to any decision maker, particularly if put in terms of transparency and accountability. Through careful positioning and the right language, you can ensure that any decision maker has a pitch they can say yes to.
